importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Tel Aviv soccer derby cancellation, marking a significant incident in Israeli sports and public safety.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time the article was updated, indicating when public information on the incident became available.

keyTakeAways: A Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder.
Police reported 12 civilians and 3 officers injured, with 9 arrests and 16 detained for questioning.
Footage showed fans throwing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades, leading authorities to cite endangerment of life as a reason for cancellation.
Hapoel criticized police for what they described as a militarized response, claiming the police had taken control of the sporting event.
Previous incidents involving Maccabi fans in England and Amsterdam have led to security bans and political backlash, including from UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
UK officials acknowledged concerns about violence in Tel Aviv and are engaging with Israeli authorities to understand the situation.

namedEntities.name: Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major city in Israel, home to the soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the soccer derby where the violent riots occurred, central to the incident's context and significance.

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major Israeli soccer club based in Tel Aviv, one of the rivals in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The opposing team in the derby that faced violent fan clashes and criticized police actions.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major Israeli soccer club based in Tel Aviv, rival to Hapoel in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The other team in the derby that faced fan-related violence and had its match canceled.

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The shared stadium in Tel Aviv where the soccer match was scheduled to take place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue of the match that was canceled due to safety concerns from fan violence.

namedEntities.name: Israel Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency responsible for managing public order during the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agency that canceled the match due to public disorder and injuries, and which faced criticism for its response.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The journalist who reported the article for CNN.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the news reporting, indicating the article's credibility and origin.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The media outlet publishing the article.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source that disseminated the news, influencing public awareness of the incident.

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The UK police force that banned Maccabi fans from attending a match in England.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UK authority involved in a previous incident that parallels the Tel Aviv violence, highlighting broader security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, who criticized the ban on Maccabi fans.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A political figure who publicly condemned the security ban, linking it to broader international concerns about fan violence and discrimination.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An English football club where Maccabi fans were banned from attending a match.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue of a previous match where security concerns led to fan bans, showing a pattern of international security issues.

namedEntities.name: Ajax (Dutch side)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Dutch football club where Maccabi fans were involved in violent scenes in Amsterdam.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: An earlier incident involving Maccabi fans that contributed to ongoing security scrutiny and international backlash.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled after violent riots and public disorder, with police reporting injuries to 12 civilians and three officers, and arrests of nine individuals. The match at Bloomfield Stadium was halted due to fan violence, including the throwing of pyrotechnics and smoke grenades, which authorities cited as posing a danger to human life. Hapoel criticized the police for a militarized and overreaching response, claiming it undermined the spirit of sports. This incident follows previous security bans on Maccabi fans in England and the Netherlands, prompting international criticism, including from UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who emphasized the importance of fan safety and inclusivity in sports.
title: Tel Aviv Soccer Derby Canceled by Police Due to 'Violent Riots'
